meta-review.comment:
Hippo Penny -!

It's that time of the year again - seasonal grok-ing season has descended upon us, and I'm thrilled to dive into Lavapotion's Songs of Conquest! As a reviewer who's all about witty humor (read: self-deprecating) and fun, I'll do my best to poke fun at myself and those esteemed critics (wink, wink).

Now, let's get this party started!

Songs of Conquest is a turn-based tactics anthology that pays homage to Heroes of Might and Magic. The game boasts gorgeous pixel art, which - if you're old enough like me - will instantly transport you back to the good ol' days of gaming (think: Diablo II's 3D graphics). But don't worry; it won't leave you feeling like a grok stuck in the past.

The battle system is where Songs of Conquest truly shines. Punishing, yet rewarding, battles are scattered throughout the game, making every victory feel earned and each defeat an opportunity to learn (or cry, but that's what tea parties are for). I mean, who doesn't love a good ol' fashioned " Ah, I should've done X instead of Y" moment?

Of course, no review would be complete without a dash of humor. When I'm not busy playing games and eating Cheetos, I'm over here wondering why Eurogamer's critic didn't simply say, "This game is nice" instead of describing it as having "a lot of heart." (Hey, I did it! Now it's your turn to laugh.)

In all seriousness, Songs of Conquest has its flaws - like any game worth playing. But what sets it apart are the well-characterized factions and the sheer amount of content Lavapotion has packed in.

So, what's my take on Songs of Conquest? Well, let me just say that I'm having a blast (literally). With so many critics raving about the game, I reckon you might want to give it a try. After all, who doesn't love a good ol' fashioned turn-based strategy game?
